Very excellent React course. Covers many topics very well. I was very disappointed to learn after purchasing that Andrei's role in this course was limited and he is hardly in any of the videos. I appreciate Yihua and I think he does very well and covers much of the content very well. The course is massive and it is very well organized. 
     While I think the course was great I find it very dishonest to list Andrei as an instructor when he, in fact, hardly contributes to the videos. Marketing this course with Andrei as an instructor when he is not the main instructor in the course was misleading and disappointing as I only purchased the course because he was listed as an instructor. Outside of that dishonesty, the course was well done although I still would've preferred Andrei.

results.content:
This course was the most in-depth React course out there for sure. There were so many topics and I was glad to have been able to complete it.  I actually completed it while at the same time starting my first job as a web developer so it took a bit longer to go through. I love Andrei's teaching style. He explains things very clearly and does a great job at helping students understand what they are doing before jumping into any code. 
My only critique and perhaps it may just be personal preference but I found it a lot harder to get through Yihua's lessons. I feel his explanations on topics were somewhat vague and when he gave definitions or explanations on certain topics it didn't actually help me get a clear understanding of what he was trying to explain and I was left more confused. He also went through the code-along lessons way too fast. Perhaps it is a different teaching style that I couldn't relate to?  Still happy with the course and am grateful for the Zero To Mastery team. I managed to change my careers and pursue a life in the tech world. All thanks to Andrei's courses!

results.content: This course, like all of the Zero to Mastery courses, is one of the best courses to learn React. If you are struggling with any concepts such as class components or state management then this course is for you. If you already know about class components and how to handle state inside of a class component but React Hooks are throwing you off your game then this course is for you. If you have heard of GraphQL and wanted to get a bit more familiar with it for querying data from the frontend then this course is for you. You will also learn about one of my favorite tools for creating frontend websites quickly and efficiently, Gatsby. Which combines the best of React with GraphQL for a very unique way of creating your website without the need or use of a backend. If you are wanting to learn of the most in demand skills for web and app development then look no further than this course.

results.content:
I highly recommend you do a modern JavaScript course before doing this React one. And I also recommend a CSS course, because he uses a lot to make things pretty and you will just paste that if you don't have the knowledge.
The Andrei video side notes are really good. After Yihua explains something new, we are still questioning some things. Then comes Andrei in another video and explains these questions. For example: on lesson 21 Yihua shows a <button onClick> and I was asking myself if that was html or jsx, and then Andrei explains exactly that on the lesson 22.
On lesson 174 - Redux Thunk, it was showed how this library is used for solving a problem. But I'd like to see the instructor teaching why we should use that library. I mean, what if we just use the async function inside the redux without the library? Ok, it will not work, or it could work but will be harder to code, but why/how? I'd like to see the problems we could have encountered, and then the need for a library like redux-thunk.
Section about GraphQL teachs on how to use an already existing Apollo server, so you'll have to learn on your own on how to build one from scratch.
This is just a personal taste, but I think I would like it more if the course consists of little projects and then a big project, because with little projects we could focus more on the feature being taught. Having just one big project, many things are mixed up right on, and for a novice on react that could be messy.
Overall, it's a good course where you will be presented to a lot of new things. With this in mind, double check if you understood the lesson, because you could get a bit lost on future lessons.

results.content:
Hello, review readers,

This course is the second of Andrei's that I have taken, and this is quite literally the first time that I have ever felt compelled to write a review for anything on any platform. Andrei presented the entirety (iirc) of Mastering the Coding Interview, and Yihua Zhang takes the reins on this React course (though Andrei does chime in intermittently). As with my prior experience, I am thoroughly impressed by and extremely grateful for the depth of content, clarity of presentation, and added experiential insights provided with regard to the topics at hand. 

As (most recently) a Lead Developer on multiple critical applications for a very large corporation, I can confidently say that I would be thrilled to work with anyone who has a true grasp of even 50% of the non-bonus content of this course, and I am equally confident that if you approach this course with an earnest effort you will finish with far more than that. You will likely have developed a foundation for more than you will be required to know for a given role, and you will also know where and how to look for what you may need to layer on top of that foundation. 

I am an obsessive learner and explorer and, given my experience thus far, for any new topic which interests me I will first be checking to see if Andrei has released a course on the subject. 

To Andrei and Yihua: Thank you both for your commitment to teaching and sharing, and I wish you much success in continuing the same.

results.content:
Not good! I've taken other courses with Andrei and I've given 5 stars to all but this is something else. It's ok at the beginning but as Yihua enters the scene it gets worse and worse. The first big one is when he finishes the script and shows you it works, all this to come back in the next lesson going "There's a mistake". The script provided skips lessons, sometimes several entire chapters and for graphql there's no final script at all. So when you have a typo you have to look back and forth trying to find the error while wondering: Did I make a mistake or did Yihua white-washe it again by fooling us that it works? 
There's a lot of repeating of things that are not important, obvious lack of planning, lack of teaching experience and most important, NO BOOK!!! Why? If the course replaces the teacher then where's the book? How fast can you find something in a video? Maybe the book should just give the important lines of script while the blabla is in the videos. Maybe the lesson titles in the book could link to the video counterparts. That way, if you need to find something, you look in the book. If you need more, you click on the title and watch the lesson.
Also, at some point one of the non-video lessons corrects the following video saying that since 2019 the apollo way has changed. You put 2020 in the course's title!!! Why wasn't this video and the ones with errors redone? How about the ones where Yihua refactors the names of variables?
Some of the mistakes in here are already huge on their own, when you add them all together, it becomes more than ridiculous.
I'm sorry Andrei but you shouldn't have attached your name to this.

results.content:
The instructor Andrei needs to slow down.  75% playback speed was necessary and I frequently had to pause the video to catch one or two seconds of key segments of video.  
 
Use of the Zoom/Focus tool was very frustrating.  A lot of instructors seem to use this technique but a lot of the time you only can see 3-4 lines of code, with popups (for extra information) and often with code Intellisense blocking out everything.  It was hard to figure out what was going on with limited code examples and jumping from one time to the next and a voice over.  It was very rushed.

Share the instructors full (VSCode) screen.
Provide separate Git commits for every code video on Github.  
Slow down speed of talking and coding.

Overrated course.

results.content:
I expected much, much better. 25% into the course I've barely seen Andrei, whose teaching methods I very much enjoy. He shows up in short videos here and there to correct or add on to something Yihua's said, but has been otherwise absent.

Yihua's teaching is, I'm sorry to say, not compatible with my learning. He jumps around between concepts and/or files, scrolls up and down sporadically, sometimes fails to show his code long enough for the user to write it down before he continues onto some other issue elsewhere (and I've not sped the video up). It feels very half-planned. Not to mention the erratic mouse movements all the time, which I can only hope doesn't distract you as much as it distracts me.

To add on to this, I wish he'd explain much more often -why- a bit of code is necessary, or why it works as it does. Just adding it and explaining where it's from is of absolutely no use.

So far for me this course is on par with YouTube tutorials; more like a code-along than an actual course designed to -teach-.

Though I will add, the course goes through a -lot- of good content, just with poor delivery (IMO); and for the low price I got it at it's still worth it for me to complete it, if only for the fact that I already have it and am past the refund date.

results.content:
Not well planned. Missing a direction and the content keeps jumping all over the place.
You may like it if you like to learn too much theory (that too unfortunately is kind of repetitive and very shallow).

response.content: Hi Ashish, not sure what you mean by too much theory? 80% of the course is us building a massive ecommerce project together that is scalable and production ready. Although we make sure that as we build this massive project, we explain WHY we are doing things so you can go off and implement decisions on your own projects. If we just coded along without explaining ourselves, it wouldn't be a very useful course for majority of students. Also, we try to mimic real life scenarios where you are working on a React app that is complex and not an easy "beginner" app that is nice and easy to watch in a video, but isn't realistic because in real life apps are complex.
response.content_html: Hi Ashish, not sure what you mean by too much theory? 80% of the course is us building a massive ecommerce project together that is scalable and production ready. Although we make sure that as we build this massive project, we explain WHY we are doing things so you can go off and implement decisions on your own projects. If we just coded along without explaining ourselves, it wouldn't be a very useful course for majority of students. Also, we try to mimic real life scenarios where you are working on a React app that is complex and not an easy "beginner" app that is nice and easy to watch in a video, but isn't realistic because in real life apps are complex.

results.content: I have to agree with earlier posters. This does seem to be an updated title and not really an updated course. This is now clear with the use of class based components which, when this course was first composed, might have had a chance to overthrow functional components and hooks. Class based components have their place but I'm reminded of Betamax.The Redux section is very quick/vague and copying along, re-watching and re-watching didn't clarify why anything was being brought in from state or passed to anything as props. A 45min YouTube video by Stephen Grider made so much sense that I bought his course in an attempt to avoid getting bogged-down with this course. I'm not saying that this course doesn't have merit, it really does, but I'll come back to it when I don't have any remaining confusion.

results.content: Putting 2021 in the course title doesn't automatically mean your course is up to date. To do this is misleading at best and downright disingenuous. Many of the concepts we go over are out of date. I saw in the comments someone said they were working on an update 6 months ago. It doesn't seem like there has been one.

response.content: Nick, we just did a big update to the course today! Go check it out... we always update our courses every year around this time, but you have to remember that the industry changes a lot in React land and it takes time for us to make these videos. That's why we do big yearly updates around Aug~October and it's impossible for us to make a change every month on ever React update. Anyway, enjoy all the new up to date content :)

The presentation of this course is very poor, the app is not accessible which is really surprising! (I’m half-way through so it may get better), the HTML layout is not semantic, the CSS is very poorly constructed. The file structure is weird at the start, but I think gets better, as you work through the course.

However, all those things are easily fixable, I'm just surprised that stuff like accessibility and semantics are not taken into contradictions when teaching (Sadly, it’s common in javascript tutorials not to care about stuff like this). Libraries as React and Redux are explained pretty well, though!

results.content:
This isn't really a course but more a tutorial. What's the difference? Basically the only thing is you see a guy coding. There is almost no learning. To typing or figuring out yourself. 
The easy parts are covered extensively, but the more difficult parts are cruised by. 
Saying 'right' after every sentence doesn't make people understand it better.
Sure there are a lot of good things in 35 hour coding. But in the end... There is almost no learning. 
While the instructors keep saying you have to learn, repeat and type code. The only thing you can do is code along. 
I wouldn't say it's a complete waste of time. A lot of effort is put in probably. But like I said... there is no learning. 
Disappointed.

results.content:
Andrei the main instructor has an excellent and thorough teaching style. 

I'm sad to say the same is not true for the other instructor, Yihua. After just a few videos from Yihua, I found myself confused and frustrated by things which hadn't been explained or had been rushed over. Then several of the next few videos were from Andrei again to explain things from Yihua's videos which "may have been confusing" aka concepts were not explained at all.

I'm actually going to be trying one of Andrei's other courses because I do believe he's an excellent teacher. As for this course, it's a pass from me. I'm sure Yihua is a great programmer, but in my opinion he needs to introduce topics properly and explain them why we do things, not just how we do them.

results.content:
When Andrei says, "Please go out and rate/review this course as a 5-star" he's telling no joke.

This is not just another React course, it's so much more than that! We can get to know about so much in the React ecosystem only by getting into this course and learning from it, building a maaaasssive project! I seriously didn't expected that I will make this type of application which includes so much! 

A very BIG thanks to Yihua for explaining all the code concepts so clearly and making a project along with him doesn't feel too distant!  Also, a thank you to the teaching assistant TY who's always there to help us.

Other courses have just the videos and the content. This Zero To Mastery (ZTM) course has videos and the massive ZTM Community. 

Thank you, everyone, for making me a complete newbie in React to where I'm now...a professional React developer :) 

Onwards to the next ZTM course...

results.content: So. Now. Right? Although I appreciate the entrepreneurial spirit of Yihua and Andrei, I think they're communication skills are weak. I am sure they are excellent programmers. They absolutely know everything there is to know about the subject. There is very little cohesion. For example, Yihua starts a lesson. Then Andrei follows with an explanation of Yihua's lesson. Which makes it two lessons. Their choice of wording is very youthful. They both speak in a boyish fashion, which makes it difficult for me to understand most concepts. Every other sentence has a "Now." Or a "So." Or a "Right?". Which is very cute, but after 24 lessons, it gets irritating. I muted a few lessons.  I was very excited about the concept of working on all of these topics, but I don't know if I will finish this course.

results.content: Overall content is pretty good, just a ton of repetition of basic coding and javascript concepts. Don't need to frequently explain how while loops work, falsy values, function declarations, what async means, etc. those types of basics are easily google-able, or at the very least should be in an appendix, not the main course. Hard to stay focused with how much time is spent on things like that. Also recommend downloading the 4x playback speed chrome extension because the speech is unbearably slow.  Definitely wouldn't have made it through this course without it. 2x speed on this course is like 1.25 on other courses I've taken, which is especially frustrating when I don't want to learn what a while loop is for the 67th time. I also wish the instructor would explain what we're doing before we do it, instead of after. It's a lot of mindlessly copying code and THEN figuring out why you wrote it, instead of going in with an idea of what's being accomplished and being able to understand why you're writing each line as you're writing it

results.content: The instructors seem to be very knowledgable about the topics and they cover React extensively with many detailed explanations. However, they need to improve on teaching methodology. There´s a permanent jumping back and forth and too many detours which are really distracting even if you know about the topics that are being explained. There´s a willingness to explain as much as possible but explanations must be graded and chosen providing opportunity to apply gradually what is being introduced. No need to explain things beyond what is needed for the specific task. That is proven to be counterproductive. I am around 1/3 of the course at the moment of writing this review.

I'm 20% in now and this seems to be a very good course, with knowledgeable instructors.
What I'm missing though are exercises and challenges. Just listening to the instructor and coding along really gives a false sense of knowing this stuff. 
and sometimes there is just too much talking! I get that these are big topics and all, but I think it's REALLY necessary to never give more than 20 mins or so of explanation before some kind of exercise or challenge.. 
I just started a project of my own, trying to use the techniques we are learning, and it's blatantly obvious that I haven't fully grasped what we have been through so far.

results.content:
I have taken many ZTM courses so far and benefited greatly. This one so far has been the most disappointing in terms of presentation. Excessive zooming in and out, quick jerky moving around and circling of the cursor, unnecessary and rapid scrolling up and down, uneven paces of speech and delivery seemingly based on over-excitement of instructor, all combined, create a distracting and disengaging experience. I need to constantly keep going back to see what the parts of videos that were zoomed out of were, just to see the whole code and try to make connections. Video editing leaves a lot to be desired. About 20% mark now, and so far it has been a painful experience to stay motivated and follow the course. I intend to finish the course but it is taking a lot of resolve to fight through all these obstacles that make it difficult to concentrate. I will change the rating if this gets better later in the course.
Lesson 72. Yihua first used file name 'preview-collection.component.jsx' and decided to change it to 'collection-preview.jsx' and drops 'component' in doing so without saying anything. I had been following his style (that had been highlighted earlier by Andrei)  so without noticing it changed it to 'collection-preview.component.jsx', following his style. I continued to follow his code later to import it from 'collection-preview' at 8:59. Later it didn't compile and ended up wasting 1.5 hours to see where the problem was. There are inconsistencies at different places and occasions where he quietly changes things without saying anything or while talking over it about something else.

results.content:
This is the best course that has ever existed, no doubt!  Andrei and Yihua are the best combination for teaching people online. 

There are several important things to point out about this course: 
#1 - complex concepts are divided into smaller parts and they are explained in simple words, which means if you have no clue about programming, if you listen carefully, understand and practice all you can become strong junior / medior after course for sure.
#2 - this project definitely resembles the challenges that might come in real-life scenario. Also, it is awesome to show someone one day what have you done.
#3 - they created a community on discord which is awesome! Basically, you can find people around the world to study with them, to work with them or to help you. Even you can find people from your region so you can speak with them in your native language.  
#4 - there are different sections on discord. You can find out about new job opportunities, about interview questions, about working experiences. There is a channel where people show what they have made, so you can get the idea of what can be done or what have they achieved with the skills they learned after the courses. 

Conclusion: I would recommend to anyone, the best-invested money on the Udemy course so far!

results.content: Great course. Worth the money. It takes you through a wonderful, progressive and comprehensive journey. It introduces you to modern web technologies in a step by step fashion while building a representative real-world application. For each significant concept, they first explain things conceptually (with diagrams). Then pragmatically (with follow-along coding examples). Afterwards, they review the concept. Finally, they describe all the tradeoffs a seasoned developer might need to make. I'd recommend it. Well done, guys! I appreciate your effort in creating this course :)

results.content:
First of all, thank you Yihua Zhang & Andrei Neagoie for coming up with this detailed ReactJS course.  

I have almost 4 years of hands on experience in ReactJS & initially I felt this course might not be much helpful for me.
But after finishing the course I felt it has helped me in understanding React library much better & also the concepts from developing, testing, building to deploying a live web application.
 
The new concepts which I learnt from this course were - firebase, Stripe payments, Redux Saga, Progressive Web Apps, GatsbyJS & multiple concepts on testing. Basic concepts are also well covered for a beginner - Zero To Mastery course for sure

I have seen multiple course contents on ReactJS in Udemy and this is one of the best course which has covered topics that are required to become a master react developer. 
I really recommend to take it!!

results.content: I must say I'm pretty disappointed in this course.  They use code/techniques from 2019 (or possibly older) and it's pretty clear they just changed the title and not much else.  I feel like I've wasted a ton of my time learning convoluted tech nobody uses anymore.  The entire section on Redux especially needs a complete overhaul as there have been major updates to Redux, Context, Hooks,  and the entire world of state management in React.  Seriously, every student comment in the Redux section is about how dated that section is.  I  tried really really hard to like this course because I have taken other courses by Andrei before but I'm sorry, this is not up to your standards.  Don't slap on a new title and think it'll pass for 2021, that's just lazy.  This course has seriously hurt your brand image.

results.content: Initially I thought Yihua didn't explain redux in detail, so I got a bit confused, but as more sections I learned, it became more and more clear to me. The later sections (after deploying section) are great and worth finishing (e.g. How to build HOCs lesson)! This course covers a lot of important practical features to learn, so I would say it's a great one to take! Only personally I think it's beyond basic, I understand this course better after finishing Andrei's Advance JavaScript Concepts course and The Complete Web Developer course, and I rewinded them a lot of times. So for those who already know JavaScript concepts well, I highly recommend taking this one, to power up your practical ability.

results.content:
Given how much I've enjoyed all of other Andrei's courses - this one has disappointed me the most. This isn't taught by Andrei personally - as I've come to witness it's someone else teaching the course.

Although I haven't finished the course 100%, I'm roughly 50% through - this course misses on key elements that are present in other courses and free courses. 

You are not challenged to test your knowledge as soon as you learn new concepts; this feels like an lecture where the lecturer is speaking and you're just taking notes.

I highly doubt i'll be completing this course, I haven't learned anything related to react given the amount of time I've spent on the course. The other teacher (Yang I think it's his name) doesn't really feel like he has engaged me in this course whereas Andrei's teaching methods does.

results.content:
I did the first part of this course a year and started again. First off, this course is NOT for beginners, I had to come back after I learned a lot more about JS (I recommend Web Dev Simplified JavaScript). I also think that the course is too ambitious, and in doing so, they are rushing along. They stop and explain, but the best way to learn is ny practice exercises. Here you are you just playing a code-along and you will not learn much that way unless you view the course for a second time and try to see if you can code it before Yihua starts.

I was checking "React for the Rest of Us" here in Udemy and that feels like the pre-requisite for this course. 

The content is great, but it could've been planned a bit better to make it easier to grasp.

results.content:
A gold mine of good info, but the actual video editing and instruction leaves something to be desired. 

I gave it 3.5 stars as a rating of value delivered over time. The delivered value is immense, but so is the time spent in the course.

I would recommend that in a course this long, the instructor take some more time to avoid duplication of effort, e.g. "oops, I made a mistake in the last video, now we'll take some time to fix my mistake." There's certainly some value in seeing that a professional also makes mistakes, but after a couple of occurrences, it just seems lazy.

I understand that there is some good reasoning behind the overlapping info in the Zero to Mastery team's courses, however, as someone who has taken a few courses by this team, I'm personally disappointed that the courses have so much duplication.

Other instructors I have followed, rather than take time from a lesson to explain something that they already explained in another course, will refer the student to said course, giving the student the option. I often waste time speeding up and slowing down the video.

results.content:
Very frustrating when early on we are told 'I use yarn but npm is fine'.  And then later in the course they only go through yarn and the command for npm is nowhere to be found.  Maybe take 5 seconds to say what the npm command would be.  Or have a resource for it.  Even the page we are given early that shows npm vs yarn commands does not have the information needed.  What is the npm command for 'yarn build'?  Or for 'yarn deploy'? 

Don't tell us "npm or yarn is a personal choice" and dont say "Don't worry if you are not sure of the below commands as we will explore them throughout the course:" when that is absolutely not the case.  

If you purchase this course, use yarn.  Otherwise you are on your own

results.content:
I like this course because of the big, real-world project. I would recommend this course after the getting very comfortable with the basics because the concepts can get advanced. 

Unlike other courses that teach you how to make many small apps or a few medium sized apps, this courses connects a whole bunch of technologies together into 1 big project. This is much better for your portfolio for this exact reason.

That being said, this course needs to be updated otherwise you can get stuck since some of the updated versions won't look like the video. For example, Firebase has made changes to the objects returned from api calls and looks completely different from what is seen in the videos. The TAs don't know what to do either about it. The code still seems to work if you follow along, correctly. The silver lining is that you will have to troubleshoot or make sense of the newer versions, thus making you a better developer.

results.content:
The first part of the course briefly explores what React is and how it works, by building a quick and fun little project. The rest of the course focus on how to properly build an entire eCommerce and dives into the inner works of React, and how it integrates with other libraries and back-end services like Firebase. Incidently this also helps to understand asynchronous code with React which is a real necessity in the industry.

I could go on but this course is well worth it, not only because of the incredible amount of topics covered but also because they are well and clearly explained. To me the most important thing of any course is the support you get from the instructors and teaching assistants; this course has it and you will be really thankful for it (it's worth going through the Q&A to see what other students already asked before).

Kudos to Andrei and Yihua, excellent material!

So, 4 stars this time.

results.content: Starts off well but over time the course becomes frustrating - writing out a lot of boilerplate / convention driven code and talking over it instead of providing examples that break down the problem. Also, I found some implementations simply bad - creating 'wrapper hell' and overengineering the solutions to routine tasks. What would make it better is providing problems that you can solve yourself and connect the dots, not just code along which is not that effective.

results.content:
There is a reason why people like me go for Andrei's courses, because he is just fantastic with his teaching skills. I bought 6 out of 8 Andrei's course after watching his Advanced JS course because he is that good. But this course is not actually Andrei's course, there is hardly any content by Andrei in this course. I have no offense towards the other instructor of this course but his teaching is no where to close Andrei's. I have chosen this course over other React courses on Udemy and I am totally disappointed. 

I personally felt that Yihua's explanation of concepts or code is missing the fundamental details and why any of his code is working the way it is, He just writes the syntax and it works but why and how is not explained. And it's evident in the course, where you see Andrei is jumping in between to explain those concepts again or you will see a text popping up on the screen a ton of times to clear up the topic.

results.content:
Hopefully i`ll promote the rate to 5 stars, but for now there is one SUPER COMMON CASE PROBLEM: see, people who buy this course are 99% not even junior developers, so it`s extremely bad practice for instructors to just comment what they are coding. Try to EXPLAIN why we do this thing and that thing. Before rushing to code it`s better to outline what we are going to do and only then do it. Imagine the person who is watching this is not capable of consuming the knowledge right away, so dedication some extra time to repeat basic things could be a good practice.   This is not the first time, when the instructor is mega-powerful-senior-superior-programmer but is not able to explain properly what he is doing. The instructor may think "Well, everything is clear and well understandable, dunno what this guy is talking about" - yep, for SENIOR developer who can handle these tasks in a heartbeat it`s understandable, but for the novices not

(Updated)
Too much rush in the course, bad explanation. As it was already mentioned it`s cool to be Senior developer, but just stick to your job, may be teaching others is not your thing. I have no clue why the course has 4.6 stars, the only awesome thing is quite extensive project. Wouldn`t recommend for novice.

results.content:
This is BARELY an Andrei course. I got this course because of all the great things about other courses he teaches but this was a huge let down.

The only pro I have for this is the project you will get to build for your portfolio, however personally I think moving past the deployment section will be time wasted. The lectures are incredibly fast and not beginner friendly at all, the main instructor Yihua just starts coding pretending you are familiar with the concepts and won't really go into detail of how and why things are done.
The Teacher Assistant is quite condescending, making students feel less with a fix it yourself attitude(at least in my experience and the responses I've read from him).

Many other great options out there, unfortunaly this isn't one of them.

results.content:
I have completed the course I just skipped stuff that was already in your other course (PWA + testing etc).

First of all I don't think this course is worth no value at all. For me who recently started programming and took 4 of your courses, Zero to mastery, Junior to Senior, Adv JS and React I obviously thought your courses were worth for me to buy all the others.

I do understand that in this field it is impossible to keep everything up to date since new things get updated very often however some of the sections are so outdated (1~2 years) and I don't really think you can call this a 2021 course in the title.

I had similar problems in other courses (other than the react one) but going through the Q&A section helped me through to this 4th course React. However the Q&A section in this  particular course is so horrible due to the current teaching assistant DAN who either has no idea what his talking about or just doesn't care. 

Its not like I am holding a personal grudge on this guy, I don't even know him. But every time I check Q&A section I get discouraged by the lack of quality in his answers to past students as well as mine. Its almost as if his picking a fight with the students. I won't go over all the effortless answers he gave in the past but really the course would be better off if he just didn't answer them at all.

As I said earlier I don't think this course is worthless as a whole, but the experience you have to deal with going through this course in 2021 is what I don't want to recommend.

response.content: Tony, we just did a big update to the course today! Go check it out... we always update our courses every year around this time, but you have to remember that the industry changes a lot in React land and it takes time for us to make these videos. That's why we do big yearly updates around Aug~October and it's impossible for us to make a change every month on ever React update. Anyway, enjoy all the new up to date content :)

I do understand that in this field it is impossible to keep everything up to date since new things get updated very often however some of the sections are so outdated (1~2 years) and I don't really think you can call this a 2021 course in the title.

I had similar problems in other courses (other than the react one) but going through the Q&A section helped me through to this 4th course React. However the Q&A section in this particular course is so horrible due to the current teaching assistant DAN who either has no idea what his talking about or just doesn't care.

Its not like I am holding a personal grudge on this guy, I don't even know him. But every time I check Q&A section I get discouraged by the lack of quality in his answers to past students as well as mine. Its almost as if his picking a fight with the students. I won't go over all the effortless answers he gave in the past but really the course would be better off if he just didn't answer them at all.

As I said earlier I don't think this course is worthless as a whole, but the experience you have to deal with going through this course in 2021 is what I don't want to recommend.

results.content:
This course is well-made. However, for me it was not the right way to learn React / Redux by doing one huge project. I finally found another modern React course that taught everything in much smaller, encapsulated projects. 

This way I found it much easier to understand the general concepts and patterns of things like redux, context, hooks, etc.
But I am sure for others this course will be good. 

One additional note: I had quite some experience with React when I started this course and still I found it too fast.

There are  many instances when the code is not working it is painful to go through all the videos to find/correct the issues. Code for start and end of each chapter should be attached to the course instead of looking at folders in Yihua's git repo.  Instructor should present the concept at the beginning  and summary end of each sections using slides with architecture and code syntax. Instead of Firebase, the course should cover mainstream databases such as PostgreSQL etc.  
The course should end with a go to cheat sheet to work on a new react project.

results.content:
In general, a really good course. There's lots of content and it's a good value. 

However, the jumping back and forth between instructors, and the sense that they are reusing bits and pieces of videos from other courses leads to the occasional dead end. For example, it's great to have the bonus "Promises" content at the end. However, that video ends with "hey, in ES7, there's this magical new async await stuff! Let's talk about that next..." followed by completely unrelated content about the use of "filter" in the next video. I'm pretty sure that the Promises stuff came from somewhere else, and maybe that somewhere else has the ES7 async/await included too, but it's not here.

Again, overall, the course is good. But it feels oddly pieced together at times and leaves you confused occasionally.
results.content_html:

results.content:
I've forced myself to continue with this course for so long but I'm leaving it now. The explanations aren't clear and the content is outdated too. The worst part is that they are not ready to acknowledge it even though most of the students share the same opinion as me. The TA is no help either. TY does make a lot of effort to answer but Dan doesn't do anything. All he says is "watch the videos again" or "thanks for the feedback" or "Idk why but here is my repo". Updating the course title doesn't update the course. You can't just make a 20-25 hours course for legacy codes. I don't understand how this course has a 4.7 rating when most of the students are frustrated by the course in the Q/A section. The advertising made me get this course and if I could ask for a refund I definitely would have. 

I don't hate the instructors or anything. In fact, I have 2 more ZTM courses but this one really was a bad purchase.

There are a lot better tutorials and courses everywhere from YouTube to Udemy. I would not recommend buying this one.

results.content: the projects in the course are completely outdated - NOT 2021 !.  The course information is quite useful, but its just really difficult to navigate the course. Sections are titled by project/component step rather than what is covered in that step. The projects definitely should have been updated as long as the course is being sold - otherwise should be free. Also whatever was done to the sound / voiceover all the captions are distorted as a result. Example JSX translates to jail sex, AJAX to sex, React Developer translates to 'reactive helper'.. so the transcripts have been rendered useless. If you rely on transcripts - this course won't work for you. Its a shame because the instructor is teaching valuable information and explains well.. but theres just so many issues with the course. If the voiceover thing was fixed, the transcripts working and the projects updated, and the navigation / organisation of material improved.. i'd give 5 stars.

results.content:
i gave it 5 stars as I'm learning a lot of new stuff here, but for beginners, it should a one start!!
 I'm just happy that I had 2 other React courses before this one!! I mean, I'm learning a lot here but feeling SO SORRY for beginners, they must have a terrible time through this course. Why? because sometimes i feel the instructor tries to show off how fast and smart he is!!!! take it easy brother!! there are beginners here, so when you bring new things on let them sink and then throw other stuff out.
And this is not only me, someone else in one the lessons left this comment talking about the same issue:
I've gotten this far in the course thanks to my ability to type 90 words per minute and enough familiarity with React after taking 4 other React courses previous to this. I've also had to pause regularly and rewind regularly anyway because this guy is just going as fast as he can possibly go. It's as if he thinks we're chasing him or something. The course is well organized, but there's just no reason to be going as fast as you possibly can when people are sitting here typing along with you AND trying to process it in their brains all at the same time.
EDITED, i moved it down to three stars as the instructor says wrong information in saga section which is the bone of how saga works!! he says actions first hit saga then reducer but it's the other way around. I'm sure about that as it was confirmed by one the saga creators here https://stackoverflow.com/questions/38607765/order-of-reducer-and-saga
P.S. the instructor has been very nice and modest and accepted the issue and promised to fix it soon though :) so I will change my rate to a nice 5 star again as soon as the fix kicks in :)

results.content: About halfway through the course so far and I will say it's got to be one of the best React courses you will find online anywhere. I bought this course on a whim but am very glad I did. I would caution anyone thinking that the course is going to be super easy. It's not. It's not impossible, but you had better have some intermediate JavaScript skills or you might get lost once Redux comes into the picture. You can go in with no React knowledge and will get the opportunity to gradually learn, but I would recommend at least dabbling with React and reading some documentation first, as the pace that they cover concepts is quite quick. Not to scare anyone away -- the challenge is a good thing. You need to be challenged to advance in this field, and this course is a very fun challenge! They will take you from shaky beginner level to extremely confident intermediate level NO problem. Will update when done with the course!

I skipped the first three sections of this course because I already have a firm grasp on the basics of React and have built a few personal projects. 

****UPDATE ****
Halfway through the Redux Sagas section and this course is worth its weight in gold, HIGHLY HIGHLY recommend! On top of learning in the course, you gain access to an amazing community of developers at all levels of competency from brand new to experienced. 

So far the master project portion of the course has been very well thought out and easy to follow. The teaching style and explanations are great and easy to understand. The quality of instruction is second to none. I have picked up tips and tricks a long the way and feel like I've already improved my react skills despite not being a complete beginner.  

Andrei's courses are always full of gold and anyone on the fence needs to give his stuff a chance. YOU WILL NOT REGRET IT :)

results.content: Overall this was a great course, covering the basics through advanced React topics along with some bonus items! However, there were a couple things I expected to be covered to truly complete the project that seemed left open-ended.  Not sure if that was intentional, but clearing the cart after purchase is pretty common and wasn't covered and a Contact link was added, but no contact page.  It also was a bit frustrating that this wasn't really a 2021 course, but an older course with little plug-ins to try and make it current, which is appreciated, but even some of those ended up out of date and had to figure out what was going wrong because of obsolete code. Still appreciate everything you taught and thankful for the separate lesson github links to be able to check against my code and figure out sometimes what I missing.  Lot's of hands-on coding was excellent.  Thank you!

results.content: I've finished a course on MERN stack (about 80-100 hours) and can say that I understand the concepts and I'm also CS student so programming isn't strange for me. Yet this course made me feel that I'm awful, teaching assistant Dan always answered the same, git clone the lesson and check the difference. While that is helpful when the problem is missing :, {} or anything similiar, it doesn't help when student is asking for an explanation as to why we do something. Lessons feel like they are sped up and you will find yourself pausing and going back a few times if you try to code along. Explanations for theory are good, but when we start coding and instructor codes so fast and talks (for me those were poor explanations) its hard to catch anything. Some things are just skipped but later included in code, and instructor never mentions them. I don't know how no one gave this course low rating while in Q&A section there are many students unsatisfied with this course and completely gave up on it. Stuff like "This course isn't for anyone" and "You have to be patient and work hard" is just laughable as the course doesn't tackle main things such as why we do something and what impact does it have. Q&A section is pretty old as the course content is, most questions as from 2019. After all, not pretty satisfied with the course, it doesn't teach you how to think in React it just makes you to code along and do it fast.

results.content:
This is 4th courses from Andrei, and I rated all previous 3 courses with 5 stars. Unfortunately this time, I can't rate with 5 stars. 

The content itself and the project we make during courses are awesome! Also, it provides in-depth explanation about React fundamentals which I couldn't get from another React courses. 

Another benefit of this course is it uses most recent features. Actually I took another course because I didn't satisfy 100% with this lecture but when I took another course, I realized that this course is way much better.

BUT! There are several problems which makes me not to rate with 5 stars.

1. I understand Yihua is a great developer, but I think he is not an excellent instructor. Andrei provides every detailed explanations and he taught knowledges very kindly so that anyone can follow. 
But Yihua relatively misses explaining "THE WHYs" of some concepts and also I can't follow his speed. I couldn't count how many times I have to stop to debug when I'm coding along. This makes me very difficult to follow the courses. He accelerates every lecture. So, so fast.

2. Luckily I have studied Javascript itself for 5 months, I could understand most tricks or concepts such as destructuring or spread operator, which I've learned from Andrei from previous courses, but there's still some concepts hard to follow.
Andrei provides full detailed explanations when he starts using some advanced concepts or tricks so that every student can understands it well, but Yihua frequently skips explanations so I need to stop and understand how it works.

I know this process is needed if I wanna become a developer, but at least I took this course to speed up learning, I think there should be more detailed explanations on some concepts.

But still, I think this is the Best React course in Udemy. I wish there are a lot more portions of lectures from Andrei. Anyway, I'm still learning a lot from this course and I'm really thankful for that. I think true feedbacks from a student are more valuable than just saying "this is best course". Thanks.

results.content:
There is a lot of good content in this course but there are also some problems. 

If a concept is needed that will be explained in a future lesson the instructors state that and move on. Compare this with Maximilian Schwarzmüller who briefly explains the concept and then says that he will cover it in more detail later - this is clearly a superior method of learning.

Second, Yihua Zhang constantly moves the mouse pointer over what he is explaining. Seriously? DUDE, stop it!!! I'm trying to READ what is under that cursor!!! Not watch you swipe, swipe, swipe. See how Andrew or Max use the mouse cursor - elegantly pointing to the code they are explaining.

Third the flow could be better, particularly because they delay explaining concepts until later. This limits the usefulness of certain lessons. At times I feel like Andrew has to come in and "save" a lesson by explaining things with another lesson. I would prefer that the original lesson was better.

This is NOT a bad course. But it isn't a great one either.

I would recommend Maximilian Schwarzmüller's course over this one.

results.content:
I took a React course here on Udemy last year, but as I was quite new to web development at that time, I didn't feel confident enough to actually sign up for a real developer job. I wanted to take one more course to deepen my knowledge - I chose this one and I'm definitely not regretting my decision! I'm still planning on doing some smaller React projects on my own, maybe taking one shorter class of Andrei's titled 'Master the coding interview' in the meanwhile, but then I think I will be all set to start my career as a web developer. :-) 
The explanations are clear, I liked the practical approach of the course (working on a larger project). I was happy to have an opportunity to study not only the basics, but also to understand some more advanced features like Redux-Saga, Context API and GraphQL. 
I have to point out that I took notes while taking the course, coded along, and always tried to explain myself after studying what was our purpose with that new piece of code and how did we achieve that functionality - only watching the videos won't be enough, in my opinion. So, after taking this course, I hope you will feel confident enough to start your own projects too! :-)

I am sure people will enjoy this, if they are new and have ALOT of time to learn this skill. In my opinion this course could be great amount shorter. If you feel that you want to make an entire "Master Project" to learn the course and get through 21 sections just to learn React Hooks, this is all you.

results.content:
Compared to the other course by Andrei that I have taken (The Complete Web Developer in 2020), this course has me confused quite a bit. 
Sometimes topics are covered extensively, and sometimes things are just dealt with in rapid fire, without much explanation why it is done the way it is, or what the different lines of code do.
I have also encountered that, while following and coding along with every video, there was a feature implemented that was not covered in a previous video...

So overall, I find this course a lot more difficult to keep myself motivated and stick with.

results.content: The instructors did an amazing job explaining not just how things in React are used, but also going into the deeper details involved. I feel like I'm getting a behind the scenes look at all of the modules that I'm using which is great for someone who has a little bit of experience and can already use some of these tools. As a current Jr developer working in the field, I learned a lot about architecture, refactoring, optimization and extending my knowledge on redux middleware. I chose to deviate from a lot of the material being taught due to things like react | redux | router hooks but the material is very relevant and very well taught. I noticed that they have also added a bunch of new material since I first bought it and restructured some parts of the course which is a huge improvement. Highly recommend this course to anyone who's played around with react for a while and has a good understanding of the basics and wants to go further.

results.content:
Well the good thing that you'll get from this course is the big portfolio project, I don't think there is another React course that has a project of this size, other than that I was a bit disappointed. Since they cram too much stuff into this course, most of the content isn't explained clearly -at least to me-, lots of times I see myself just copying what the instructor is typing without really understanding things really well, and the instructor types a bit faster than what I'm used to, there is also two instructors which feels a bit weird to me, I would rather have just one instructor.
To summarize, I don't think the course is suitable for a react beginner or to someone who wants to understand it clearly, you would be better of with some of the other courses, I suggest Andrew Mead's, But if you already know some react and want to have a big portfolio project then this course may be good for you.
Also I tried to refund the course after watching about 16% of the course, but according to udemy I watched too much of the course to request a refund, so buyers beware.

results.content:
I don't normally leave reviews for courses even if they are bad, but I am doing so for this course because I had high expectations and I feel like things can be improved to make this one of the best courses on Udemy. As a complete beginner, I expected detailed explanations. Right from the setup, the various files and the contents in the files.  The course starts with so many confusing files with populated codes everywhere and some commented out. I found it difficult keeping up. Yihua explains nothing, he's only typing his codes and talking to his fellow "experts". The other guy is good and explains better. 
I suggest the folders containing the files should be clean and take things a step at a time especially for the beginners. That said, I wouldn't recommend this course for a complete beginner.

The instructors are obviously experienced developers with a good ability to share their knowledge. The content is equable divided and each chapter sticks to the subject.
The main issues is of a technical nature: the zoom level is too heigh so the code lines get cut at around 50 characters which is far less from enough. results.content: I rarely give reviews for online courses I've taken, but this one is so amazing I have to jump here and leave the 2 instructors some true compliments. Andrei and Yihua always make sure their students understand completely every corner of the problem and not just code along like a parrot or ignore any minor thing. I truly get fascinated by their massive range of knowledge about React and everything related to it. For the first time, I understand the concepts of package managers, Babel, Webpack, lock files, how React really works under the hood, etc etc.. Trust me, I have searched these up multiple times before this course, and you'll never find anywhere that explains them as well as Andrei and Yihua did. Words fail me to describe how much I'm happy and satisfied with this course! <3

results.content:
Pros of this course:
1. Detailed code explainations of libraries and concepts involved in React Developer toolkit.
2. Each video feels like a simulation of real world scenario where a senior instructor is explaining me the code.
3. Lots of technical concepts that are not directly part of React development also covered to provide realistic web development experience. 
4.  No other course can beat this one in terms of amount of content, quality of content and the quality of the master project. 
5. The sheer effort put up by the instructors is immensely motivating  and encourage us to explore further into the content.

results.content:
The content is excellent. On par if not better than other superb educators such as Dan Wahlin. 

One thing prevents a five star rating: if you are simply listening along on this course you may well give it a five star. If you are coding along you may find as I have that it can be an incredibly frustrating experience.

At times the cadence plods along but when it comes time to do actual coding he types incredibly fast (and I'm a very fast typer) and moves along or scrolls out of view of what he just wrote. You will find yourself forever switching from your editor to pause and go backwards just to catch one little thing he typed that you weren't sure about. Maybe I'm alone in this criticism but that's my feedback.

results.content:
Content is great, instructors are knowledgeable. I haven't used React in a while but I was interested in the Firebase integrations. This got me up to speed on both. 

Critiques: 

Transitions away from coding are often instant which makes it  difficult to scroll back & pause to the < 1 second part of the video where the screen shows the last section of code completed.

He also writes very long lines, before refactoring them into multiple lines. Code written on the very edge of the video is difficult to follow.

The zoom-in work is also unnecessary and disorienting as you can't see the name of the file being worked on.

They make CSS available as downloads when there are repositories with the files they could have linked to. We're using editors, it's much easier to copy and paste than download, uncompress, open, and copy/paste.

Lastly, instructors should not use cursive fonts. It's more difficult to read than standard fonts and serves no purpose beyond style.

results.content:
This course is just okay. Most of the course has you working on a single project, which in theory is a good way to dive deeper into advanced concepts, but instead you spend the 2nd half of the course refactoring without adding anything new or making any significant changes. Refactoring is important, but the course didn't do a good job explaining why I would want to, say, use redux-saga over plain Redux + redux-thunk, since the functionality and structure were effectively the same (and the course project isn't complex enough to highlight any advantages).

I was also looking forward to the section on testing, but the actual content was ripped from another course, and the "exercise" at the end of the section was to simply write your own tests for the project, without any guidance apart from a Github repo showing the instructor's results. That's the same level of instruction I could get from YouTube videos, so it's disappointing to see it in a Udemy course.

results.content:
This class far the course has been incredibly educational and is true to its description. The instructors are absolutely great at presenting the material in an easy to understand manner. 10/10 would take another class from them. I feel much more confident in React and Firebase than I previously did.

Update Section 24: The GraphQL section content was good, but my environment was a mess setting up because of some peer dependency issues. This wasn't touched on in the section or addressed in the Q&A.

Update After Completion: The course was definitely good and was a beneficial experience. Overall I'd definitely recommend this to a fresh developer or even a developer wanting to learn more about React.

results.content: This course goes from 0 to 100 really quick. The teaching method taught in this course is not very effective in my opinion since it jumps from a semi-easy first project of monsters_rolodex to a complex eCommerce project. I have to spend hrs trying to figure out why the instructor wrote his code in a certain way, learning Routes elsewhere and some SASS etc. This feels more like a watch and code along video teaching method which ends up wasting more time trying to complete this course since I have to practice other things. I wouldn't mind buying a course where I can learn all of this section by section with some practice projects for each new technologies we're learning in this course. For example, Learning react basics. At the end of that section, build a simple project with a single page. Next course, Routes. At the end build, a simple static page where you implement Routing navigating to different pages etc. Next course, How to build a log in page. Next, small project, build a simple static Log In page. That way, we get the coding experience by actually practicing using those skills we just learned, learning from the mistakes along the way building those simple project exercises. At the end of the course, we can then combine everything we learned and build a simple eCommerce site. This course for me just feels like for like an intermediate level ReactJS developer and not feeling like the true "Zero to Mastery". One thing that I had is that it includes Sass which I have no knowledge about. If you're going to include Sass, bootstrap etc in this course, add that lesson in the course because while I'm doing this course, it's making me thing...ok, now I have to learn Sass and more CSS after this course so I can explain in the interview how I know how to use Sass, bootstrap etc. Yes, I can learn it after this course but this just feels like an Info dump on the person doing this course and not truly understanding everything while trying to code along and learn.

results.content: Initially gave 4 stars because Udemy prompted me to give a review roughly 3 videos in to a 300+ video course. Now that I'm nearly 100 videos in and have learned so much, I'm confident giving the instructors 5 stars. This course has excellent, up-to-date content, and takes great care to explain concepts and methodology completely. You don't just learn by rote repeating what they're doing - they explain why they do what they do and often ask you to stop and think about why something is worth doing and where you would use it. Excellent course, happy I purchased it.

results.content:
I think the level of the class was a good fit for my skills as someone with a decent amount of experience using React and JS in general. I like that the course is really comprehensive and that the basics section is thorough. 

However, once the projects get going, the instructors seem to roll through the tasks quickly without explaining the concepts in much detail. There is a lot of glossing over like "okay now we'll write a function called xyz to null out the state"... okay but WHY do we need to do this? what purpose does it serve? and WHY is this certain function async? etc, etc. I can think of so many examples throughout the course where nothing was explained, just performed. This makes it really difficult or impossible to apply the logic to a future project situation.

A side note: there are lots of mistakes throughout the project tasks where the instructor has to go back and fix the code or add an annotation. These should be fixed in the video before its published!! This greatly increases the likelihood of the students introducing bugs into their code or being totally confused. A bunch of the features in my projects ended up broken after following along with the videos and losing my place. There are even instances where the instructor doesn't mention which file is being edited, they just fix the typo and move on. Please try and improve these points for the future! Thanks.

results.content:
Yihua seems to really know what he's talking about, and I like how thorough he is in showing you the whole process. There is a ton to learn from this course! They definitely give you your money's worth. 

My only constructive criticism is that the instructor moves VERY quickly, so I have to pause the video every five seconds to keep up with what's happening.  I wish the instructor would slow down sometimes and take a breath to elaborate a little more on whats going on, or to take a second to note that he's opening a new file. It is cool as a programmer he's able to jump around files so quickly, but as a student trying to learn from watching him it's SO HARD for me to keep up. I think it would be super helpful if Yihua would announce which file he's opening up before he does it and give the students a few seconds to catch up. Same with any changes he's making - announce it before it happens, give everyone some time after the change has been made to hear a more thorough explanation and finish typing up the new lines of code, and keep the camera on the new file so we can see exactly what to write.

Thats just my two cents. Otherwise - GREAT course you guys! Very satisfied with this class and happy with the immense amount of information packed into it. ZTM classes are hands down my favorite on Udemy. Highly recommend!

results.content:
General comment on the course. 

This is a great class, and it is clear from the get go that the two teachers know exactly what they are doing. 

However, the format of changing from one teacher to the next within the same sequence, makes it difficult to follow along those sections and to keep a train of thoughts on topic.

If I can say, it also makes it look like that sometimes the sections are not in the right order ... but it is just an impression, probably because I have been re-listening 2 to 3 times some of the sequences to get me out of trouble.  

Nonetheless, it is a great class and there is lots and lots of valuable content in it and it touches several topics along the way, which is a great thing for someone searching for a deeper understanding of how to use React in real-life. 

Give it a though on the delivery sequence, which is to keep it to a single teacher per sections. It could avoid having people to drop out and ask for refunds. 

Cheers. 

PS: I am still giving it a 4 stars.

results.content: At first, code is far more typos-less what is great improvement against basic ZtoM Complete Web developer course, all thumbs up for this. Also absolutely great explained basics of react, clear and easy to understand. On the other hand, when we are going thru Master Project sections, it is very likely to lose track because everything is explained 1-2 times maximum and Yihua is not looking back, just still adding new and new words to remember. I got confused really soon because of this, but some of the concepts came more clear when I was going through next lessons. If React is new thing to you, it is impossible to get everything on a first go, but once you get understand all the concepts of a course, you can be sure that you're in the top 10% React developers. I think you very probably will not need all of these for your career, but whenever it will be needed - this course is great library to find knowledge. Big thank you again Andrei and Yihua for my second completed course.

results.content:
Nobody ever in their journey learns just ReactJS to become a frontend Dev. CSS is a must too. And most of us learn CSS basics and dive into Frameworks like React so that simultaneously we will learn CSS by building the projects. And that's exactly what I did, and the course prerequisites says basics of CSS. But hold on, in the lecture the instructor doesn't write a single line of CSS, instead he pastes the whole CSS file. I do understand that it's not a CSS course, but at least he should write the code without the explaining in depth. 

2) Now the second part seems like the course isn't well scripted before. It seems that Yihua recorded most of the course and Andrew cross checked and added some videos in between which doesn't follow along. 

My Recommendation: Please go to youtube and do a crash course kind of thing if you never worked with React or any other frontend framework, then it may seem familiar. Otherwise you'll be lost.

2) Now the second part seems like the course isn't well scripted before. It seems that Yihua recorded most of the course and Andrew cross checked and added some videos in between which doesn't follow along.

results.content:
Main issue was Teaching class based component and Lifecycle method with full Project and Ending with little bit of Hooks and functional based component. 

If it would have been reversed and more focus on Functional Components and Hooks. Then It would have been Properly called React 2021. 

Every Project now days uses Functional Components and Hooks.

results.content:
Initial Review is that not much good explanation is given of concepts and the instructors believe that you have some prior knowledgeof React or other frameworks. I came to this course after doing full bootcamps of Vanilla JS and still struggling as many concepts are just glossed over.

Some kinds of PDF diagrams should be given instead Yihua just moves swiftly thru important concepts. This is not a learner friendly course. I wasted too many hours.
Yihua might be a great developer but he can't teach and especially complex topics. The 2 main things an instructor needs : 
1. Putting self in learner's place and think on topics that he faced difficulty in learning and then lay importance on those concepts. 
2. Have a knack to explain complex and hard stuff in easy way by techniques like  breaking up the concept in parts, or using analogies. Very disappointed with this course.

results.content:
Hello. This has been a very good course. This is actually my second course I take on Udemy regarding React. I am a web developer for many years, but I've had most experience with AngularJS, and more old technologies (I started coding in JavaScript in the year 2000, with notepad, and almost no resources online, when Internet Explorer was ruling the web) like jQuery, and just vanilla HTML, CSS and JS.
I think Andrei and Yihua's explanations were really good. I like the fact you get the fundamentals and basic ideas, sometimes shown with charts, before you deep-dive into the thing itself. My knowledge and understanding of the React ecosystem is now better.
I have also enjoyed how you got to a point where the app is implemented with Redux, and then you keep going back to this point and refactor the entire codebase to work with different features like Hooks and Context, etc.
It's also nice that you get to learn some things beyond React itself, like how to work wit Firebase and GatsbyJs.
However, there is something I like less, and it's the fact that the newer features of React are not presented as thoroughly as the older ones. This course is named “Complete React Developer in 2020”, so I would expect React Hooks feature to get a lot of spotlight. Hooks like useCallback and useMemo are explained flawlessly, in your amazing way that makes even the most beginner understand the subject easily, but I would love to see some real-life scenarios where you would need to use these features, just like you splendidly did with the older features. I do understand that once these videos are made, you are kind of limited with enriching them when new material comes out. It's tricky. But it is kind of strange to me that a React course for 2020 doesn't even mention "refs" and the important cases where you need to use "React.forwardRef", like with HOCs.
These are the only reasons why I gave a 4.5/5 starts and not 5/5, because the rest is really excellent!
Thank you for this course. You can be rest assured that you've taught me well and my new knowledge will help me in my career.
Keep up the very good work!
Eran

results.content: A few months before discovering Andrei and Yihua’s Complete React Developer Course, I spent over $1,000 on another learning platform's React course. I completed that course with an overly priced certificate in my hand, lost, pumped with outdated info, unconfident as a React developer, and lacking a strong project for my portfolio. That course only covered about 20% of what Andrei and Yihua covered and they did not destructure the content as simply and eloquently as Andrei and Yihua do. Andrei and Yihua put in the effort to keep the course’s material updated, easy to understand, and packed with everything a React developer needs to know for the fraction of the price that other courses will charge you. I’ve completed Andrei and Yihua’s course feeling completely confident as a React developer and with a working project for my portfolio, which has a lot more value than a piece of paper. I am so glad I discovered this course. If the other course costs $1,000, then this course should be valued at $10,000. It’s a steal!

results.content:
I'm a few sections within the master project and I'm wholesomely unimpressed. 

The presentation and course structure seems to be done with little forethought. The instructor keeps bouncing around to different folders and files, while copying and pasting code from outside references without notifying the students of what is happening when those outside references are being referenced.

The distracting oversized mouse movements along with the "stream of consciousness" narration make it very difficult to comprehend the material without constantly needing to pause the video in order to figure out what exactly the instructor is trying to do.

I found the pacing, the narration, and the overall teaching style to be too unorganized and distracting. Although the course is broken up into sections, it seems as if the sections were created after the course was recorded in order to organize the content to work with the Udemy platform. 

I took this course with the intention of being able to (at a high level) understand how to approach developing a large project from conception to deployment. After coding along through the first couple sections, I realized that not only would I have to work hard to understand the videos, but I would also need to work hard to gain that "high-level" understanding of how a senior developer tackles such a large project.

I'm sure the instructor Yihua Zhang is a great developer, but the execution of this particular course wasn't the best.

I wish them nothing but the best, but I'll be refunding this one.

response.content: Steven, you have only completed about 15% of the course. The goal of the course is to prepare you for the real world where the projects are large and you aren't building something small and easy that you see in all tutorials. We show you how to code when you start working for companies, and the Master Project we build is complex because that is how we get you ready to work at places like Google and Amazon (which some of my students work at now). I encourage you to not give up... the tough parts of the course are what will make you excel and become better. Otherwise, if it was easy, everyone would be doing it :)

results.content:
Both Yihua and Andrei know their stuff and that's apparent from the word go with this course.

The main project that you build is a meaty challenge to sink your teeth into and really get to grips with the React ecosystem. It has real practical value to you in that it brings together various concepts, patterns and tools into something familiar - an eCommerce app.

I've been a late adopter when it comes to React, I knew a little to get by but it was surface knowledge. I was really pleasantly surprised with the depth both instructors go into whilst somehow keeping it concise. They're brilliant communicators.

I feel like I know where I stand with React now and moving the businesses' eCommerce and CMS sites over to headless offerings looks much more realistic. I can see exactly how I'd implement these improvements big and small, thanks to this course.

In addition to this, both Andrei and Yihua spice the content up with some solid advice surrounding software development in general. Some of which you may have heard or thought yourself, which reassures you that you're doing the right thing. Other snippets may be new and there you go, you've learned something else. New tools in your arsenal gifted from some of the best in the biz. That has real value.

So if you buy this, it'll be worth every penny. I'll be recommending we use this for onboarding and training members of our team with React when necessary.

Thank you both!

P.S. Looking forward to diving into the bonus content too!

The main project that you build is a meaty challenge to sink your teeth into and really get to grips with the React ecosystem. It has real practical value to you in that it brings together various concepts, patterns and tools into something familiar - an eCommerce app.

I've been a late adopter when it comes to React, I knew a little to get by but it was surface knowledge. I was really pleasantly surprised with the depth both instructors go into whilst somehow keeping it concise. They're brilliant communicators.

I feel like I know where I stand with React now and moving the businesses' eCommerce and CMS sites over to headless offerings looks much more realistic. I can see exactly how I'd implement these improvements big and small, thanks to this course.

In addition to this, both Andrei and Yihua spice the content up with some solid advice surrounding software development in general. Some of which you may have heard or thought yourself, which reassures you that you're doing the right thing. Other snippets may be new and there you go, you've learned something else. New tools in your arsenal gifted from some of the best in the biz. That has real value.

So if you buy this, it'll be worth every penny. I'll be recommending we use this for onboarding and training members of our team with React when necessary.

Thank you both!

P.S. Looking forward to diving into the bonus content too!

results.content:
Solid course for those who already had an experience with React. For complete beginners I think it would be somewhat hard to grasp at first. Hooks were reviewed briefly imo. Redux, GraphQL were used with older patterns, excluding hooks. 
Things not mentioned:
-Inline rendering with Logical && Operator
-Refs, useRef
-Portals
-Render props
-useImperativeHandle, useLayoutEffect, useDebugValue
-Redux Toolkit

response.content: Emma, we just did a big update to the course today! Go check it out... we always update our courses every year around this time, but you have to remember that the industry changes a lot in React land and it takes time for us to make these videos. results.content: This course simply feels like a code-along project. You will copy what the instructor is doing. However, theres not much to learn. The instructor will explain things as you move through, but if you dont have any experience with react or redux, then you could hardly call this a react mastery class. It's simply an introduction to all of these technologies, with a nice project you have built at the end. Dont expect any practice or any exercises. It is one large project that you follow along with the instructor.
