results.content: The explanation seems clear and straight through. The consideration and orders of the topics are very cool. Everything is so good. But, the one point which can be improved. There is a pretty cool comparison between every tool or library we chose. But it could be better if we can get a broader view inside that library itself. For example, what is going under the hood when we use any functionality provided by the library or package. Although, The quality of content is great and the course is almost perfect for beginner to intermediate developers (at such a low price.)

results.content:
As usual I start from 5 stars, and which thing I don't like I cut a star but after If I like something I add it back.

When I saw 48 minutes before coding 1 single line of code, explained concepts and everything I was happy. 

But after that Yshua started to explain / code, and after each 2-3 videos you Andrei come back to explain what he missed or what he wanted to say... which was a 'dance' that personally added confusion not clarity.
- The most thing I did not liked / understood ( I know ... i know i will go to read the doc ), but on routes was an explation so unclear for me, the structure of the project made no sense sometimes... 

I'm still viewing the course, we will se if we go with less stars or more.

Overall... of course we appreciate the course that is so huge, but I would prefer a better explanation not a bigger course

results.content:
am halfway through the course.  I am an iOS developer by trade, but I have taken other React courses before.  I must say this course has no equal.  It is the most thoroughly explained (while not being overly verbose) course I've taken on this subject.  I love the data-driven approach and the focus on crafting clean code.

There are no contrived examples to be found here.  Every project mimics what writing production code would be like. I feel confident in my understanding of React and its principles in a way I never imagined I could have.  


  Thanks so much for this course.

results.content:
Course completed: The topics are very well organised and the course talks about very complex things but I feel like in a lot of parts the instructor goes to fast and doesn't explain enough and I find myself reaching for other resources a lot but at the end I realized that it was all worth it because for a 30+ hours course it's freaking incredible how advanced it gets. So if you feel stupid all the time, just be patient, rewatch, and understand the concept. It may take reviewing the course 3 times and then some parts again and again when you will use them at work. I also did React by Colt Steel and Stephen Grider and altough they explain the basics very well, the material is only maybe 30% of what this course offers. This course if you stay on it can make you a mid-developer easy. The only parts that I don't really find usefull in may 2020 are GraphQL and Gatsby. Gatsby can be good but not for a junior. 
Conclusion: This is a must have course but don't expect to use only this course. You will feel confused a lot and for those times you must reach to another course or article and that's fine. 
One advice: If you feel confused, just take some days to rewatch on 1.5x again and again. It's amazing how the first time nothing makes sense, the second time some thing connect, the third a lot of things and so on. I wanted to give 4 stars because there are parts when Yihua goes to fast and doesn't cover the topics enough but this course simply amazed me at the end.
results.content_html:
Course completed: The topics are very well organised and the course talks about very complex things but I feel like in a lot of parts the instructor goes to fast and doesn't explain enough and I find myself reaching for other resources a lot but at the end I realized that it was all worth it because for a 30+ hours course it's freaking incredible how advanced it gets. So if you feel stupid all the time, just be patient, rewatch, and understand the concept. It may take reviewing the course 3 times and then some parts again and again when you will use them at work. I also did React by Colt Steel and Stephen Grider and altough they explain the basics very well, the material is only maybe 30% of what this course offers. This course if you stay on it can make you a mid-developer easy. The only parts that I don't really find usefull in may 2020 are GraphQL and Gatsby. Gatsby can be good but not for a junior.
Conclusion: This is a must have course but don't expect to use only this course. You will feel confused a lot and for those times you must reach to another course or article and that's fine.
One advice: If you feel confused, just take some days to rewatch on 1.5x again and again. It's amazing how the first time nothing makes sense, the second time some thing connect, the third a lot of things and so on. I wanted to give 4 stars because there are parts when Yihua goes to fast and doesn't cover the topics enough but this course simply amazed me at the end.

results.content:
1. Structure: I have some experience with React coming in and I can tell you that the course is structured poorly for learning: Concepts are dealt with as they come up in the creation of the main application. While this is natural for development it is not ideal for learning. The jumping around and long detours into non-React technologies make it difficult to focus on building React knowledge and skills. Sure, you will build a somewhat cool application but you will not develop the understanding you need unless you go through the course a couple of times and do a lot of outside research and practice. Solution(s): The theory/basics sections should be shorter and woven into the actual building process. Consider creating more applications to allow for consolidating knowledge/skills before moving on the more complicated material.

2. Delivery: The presentation makes it difficult to follow and code along. The instructor will often type code then navigate away from it almost immediately. Also, while he is typing the suggestions and definitions provided by VS Code often obscures the code from the screen. These two things make it necessary to rewatch sections multiple times and pause very often at exactly the right moment to actually see the code. They do have the completed code on Github and that does help but trying to code along with the course itself a real headache. The instructor also has a habit of moving his cursor in furious circles to point out important concepts or code. This practice draws the eye to the cursor itself not the code or words on screen. Solution(s): Keep the student more in mind when recording videos and editing videos. Linger on the just-completed code longer to make it easier to code along. Highlight important code instead of using the cursor to draw imaginary circles.

import { getAuth, GoogleAuthProvider, signInWithPopup } from 'firebase/auth';

const config = {
apiKey: "AIzaSyBrSO226iIVvl79DyUCsCLwAUfqzf7_q3I",
authDomain: "reactix-7170c.firebaseapp.com",
projectId: "reactix-7170c",
storageBucket: "reactix-7170c.appspot.com",
messagingSenderId: "455860143065",
appId: "1:455860143065:web:8fe71af194408a1eb18fc8"
};

const app = initializeApp(config);
export const auth = getAuth(app);
export const firestore = getFirestore(app);

export const createUserProfileDocument = async (userAuth, additionalData) => {
if (!userAuth) return;

const userRef = await doc(firestore, "users" , `${userAuth.uid}`);

const snapShot = getDoc(userRef);

if (!snapShot.exists) {
const { displayName, email } = userAuth;
const createdAt = new Date();
try {
await setDoc(doc(firestore, "users", `${userAuth.uid}`),{
displayName,
email,
createdAt,
...additionalData
});
} catch (error) {
console.log('error creating user', error.message);
}
}

return userRef;

If you're a beginner, stay away. The course claims to be beginner-friendly, but that is a lie. Keep in mind, I have experience with Java, Python, and JavaScript.

Three stars, because the beginning was nice. They taught me GitHub pages and other miscellaneous topics. 

However, get to 1/3 of the course and it's full of errors/holes. I'm 30% complete and nearly every code is outdated or broken. Copy the code exactly as the instructor, oops it doesn't work! I hate that I spent already this much time, but I won't let Sunk Cost fallacy take over.

Part of me is worried how deep these errors get when we get further and deeper in the code.

If you want to waste your time, go right ahead. You have been warned!

results.content:
There's a lot of good content in the course. The explanation/conceptual slides are good, but where things start to go downhill is once you start to program, which is the bulk of the course. The pace of programming is too fast and the instructor doing that portion of the course doesn't explain the code in detail or reemphasize content.   When you move from one video to the other it's as if you're supposed to be a master of what you've done so far which more than likely isn't the case. This could be improved if there were materials (practices or problem sets) that students could use to practice and try to get a better grasp on the concepts and moving parts but there are no such self paced practices. All the course provides is the videos and really the code that you're supposed to follow along with. Since React is designed so that you have a bunch of reusable components, as the course progresses it becomes more and more difficult to remember (especially once you get to the Redux section) what's going on and what some of the things done previously were, which the instructor doesn't re-emphasize.  As a beginner I would not recommend this course to another beginner. Most of the value comes from being exposed to different parts of React so that you can then look into things yourself and have some code to potentially reference when working on a project.
TLDR: 
Pros: Good content, good concepts explained in the few slide sections.
Cons: Not good for beginners, no problem sets/materials to try to build better intuition, fast paced and vague during the bulk of the programming parts of the course.

results.content:
I'm at 50% complete. Good thing about this course is, it is informative and you gain the knowledge of complete project. 

On the negative side, its hard to get the complete picture of how things are connected and you loose track quickly. 

Yihua teaching is like a running commentary. He suggests to code along, but its not easy. Of course you can slow the video, but still, I had to pause or go back or replay to grasp the concepts and code along. 

Some of the concepts are not explained well. Eg: mapStateToProps and mapDispatchToProps. I had to read else where to understand this

Duration of this course is 40hrs. But beware this is just to watch and complete the course. And theres no way, you are going to complete this in straight 40hrs. To really grasp the concepts and understand, you will have to re do this quite a few times, which is more frustrating and time consuming

As some of the reviews stated, if the tutor gave a clear picture of what he's about to do, or what he's done, and took time to breath in between, that would have connected well.

results.content:
tl;dr: This course is mainly taught by Yihua, not Andrei and is not beginner friendly. You will learn real world project architecture. The Content coverage is good but explanation is not comprehensive. Yihua is a professional coder but not a good teacher. His style is code fast, switch windows fast, zoom in & out constantly, speak fast (no subtitle available), and skip some complex explanation.

First most important piece of info: This is NOT a course by Andrei, it is by Yihua. 95% of the content is done & taught by Yihua. If you look for couse by Anderi, this is not!

The course advertised as for beginner but indeed it's not for beginner. I talked to others and they agreed on this. Yes, it started with simple stuff (by Andrei) which is really good. But down the road, it's all by Yihua and that is where things get worse. There are things taught by Yihua which Andrei himself not agreed upon.

Little background about myself. I'm from training & consultant industry so training & teaching is my field.

The positive sides:
The content coverage is really good. You basically learnt a lot of the real industry standard stuff and practices. There are graphical explanation which is good at introducing complex topic. Yihua also have deep understanding about his topic.

The negative sides:
The main negative aspect is a person, who is Yihua himself. If you read all the reviews & Q&A (inside the course), you will notice many students complain about his style. Here is my shot:

Yihua recorded all the lecture videos WITHOUT learner point of view in mind. Let me explain. You must understand when the student on the other side of the screen watching and coding along, the constantly zoom in & out and switching windows rapidly here and it is a terrible experience to follow along. His coding speed is lightning fast, even find the right timing to pause the video is challenging.

He speaks fast. From learning perspective, learners' mind need to stop & think about particulat point. But he chunk in all points into few fast pace sentences. I tried to slow down the video and that helps a bit, but not much.
When you see a Udemy course a relies too much on Q&A to really explain things, you can confirm that the lecture videos are done poorly. There are times when things need to explain clearly, but he didn't. Because he didn't have the learner's mind in hand. He thinks more in his own shoes than student's when recording.

I notice there are many times when a complicated topic is done explaining, he will follow by something like this: "This topic tough & complicated, if you don't understand it, it is perfectly fine." I'm sorry, I purchase & attend a course to understand & learn things, thus, it's not okay if you fail to explaining things.

I guess all the student will instantly feel how pleasant it is to watch video by Andrei when Andrei suddenly popups in one of those video to loosen the tension.

About the teaching assistants:
TY is the best of all. The amount of effort he put in answer question amazed me. I would like to personally think him for his contribution. He dive deep into questioner's mind and explain things in great details. May all the best thing happens in your life TY.

On the other hand, Dan is the worst I have ever seen. Almost all his answer is very perfunctory. To a point that I almost wanted to put a remark in my question that said: "Dear Dan, please don't reply my question, I prefer other TA." But it's not polite to do so. Therefore, the best thing to do is review here so that all people in 0ToMastery can see.

Final words:
I'm not one of those student who purchased many courses and never finish any of them. I'm opposite of those. I'm very persistent & discipline that I must finish one whole course before proceeding to the next one. Because I have plan my learning journey well in advance to acquire knowledge step by step to build solid foundation. This is the first time that a course forces me to break my own rule. I have made a decision to stop at 55% (before Redux-Saga) & I feel bad about myself now.

To Yihua:
Please research and attend topic and courses about how to deliver knowledge, how learners learn and how to design online learning experience. You are a good professional coder, but admit it, you are not a good teacher.

I was a little disappointed that I was expecting Andrei to teach the course and instead got Yihua, but the content was still very good.

results.content:
Redux is explained very well. It makes a lot of sense now. I am surprized though that this course starts teaching React as if hooks did not exist. Another great thing about the course is that Yihua shows a professional looking folder and file structure. Everything is in its place. Unfortunately, styling is not discussed in detail but CSS code is just provided as an attachment to the lesson instead. It would be nice to hear how the layout was designed. Often times, the code written by Yihua is hard to examine because it stays on the screen for a few seconds only or because it is hidden behind the auto complete popup or other overlays.  Some explanations are vague and do not state the point. I clearly understand why an HOC was used for the spinner but I can see why so many people complained about it. This new concept came up in the middle of solving completely unrelated issues.
Too many libraries are brought in when learning about redux. It would have been better to show more examples of using redux itself for practice. Redux is confusing enough but together with redux-thunk and redux-saga it gets way too complicated very soon. I get the point that the course tries to teach many different things so that students have some familiarity with everything but building a good foundation would have been much more useful in my opinion.
The section about context API is absolutely perfect!! Through repeating the same pattern it makes very clear how Contexts and Providers are used. The point of doing this is explained several times. I enjoyed this part the most.

results.content:
Pros: 
+ Large, helpful community in the Discord

+ Q&As are answered (not the case for all Udemy courses, despite what the instructors say. But what can ya do? There are a lot of people on this platform. Can't get to everyone always.)

+ Consistent communication from the ZTM team on updates in the larger development community. You can sign up for it without this course, but this is how I found out about it. 

Cons:
+ It can take a while to have questions answered, but like I said, that's to be expected.

+ It seems like the course is kind of disorganized at times. You will add a link in the nav bar of your main project to a contact page, but never add that contact page. I asked about this in the Q&A, and was told that 'it was left as a coding challenge' but truthfully, after that link is added, it's never brought up again. If it were left as a challenge, I would expect that to be stated in the course. It seems like they just forgot about it entirely. Also, that's something super useful, so I was disappointed this wasn't included. 

+ Take this with a grain of salt, but the course seems a bit outdated. I couldn't do the Apollo section at all with the code that I cloned from GitHub, and I never could find a fix. I ended up just watching the videos in the section, and deciding that if I ever did want to add Apollo to a project, I would do it from the beginning and maybe use those videos as a reference. Really, I wouldn't suggest cloning repos down in this course if you don't have to. 

+ I found the sheer amount of refactoring to be pretty annoying, but that's just me. This wasn't a SASS course, so it's beyond me that all of the styling was SASS and then refactored later to use styled components. If we were going to end up with styled components in the end, I don't know why we didn't just start there. Also, personal preference here, but I really don't see the point of styled components still. 

+ I saw this mentioned in the Q&A, but I'll mention it here as well: often, when new code is being written, it's at the very bottom of the screen. If have anything at all on the bottom of the screen (captions, time-lapse-bar-thing (what is that thing called?)), you're not going to be able to see what's being written. 

Overall, even though it seems like I had a largely negative experience from this review, I would say the course was net positive. I'm glad I did it at least, extra practice never hurt anyone; but I think you will have to look past some of the info and find your own solutions. 

And if the ZTM ever wants to add that contact page after all...I think you should.

Really, I wouldn't suggest cloning repos down in this course if you don't have to.

+ I found the sheer amount of refactoring to be pretty annoying, but that's just me. This wasn't a SASS course, so it's beyond me that all of the styling was SASS and then refactored later to use styled components. If we were going to end up with styled components in the end, I don't know why we didn't just start there. Also, personal preference here, but I really don't see the point of styled components still.

+ I saw this mentioned in the Q&A, but I'll mention it here as well: often, when new code is being written, it's at the very bottom of the screen. If have anything at all on the bottom of the screen (captions, time-lapse-bar-thing (what is that thing called?)), you're not going to be able to see what's being written.

Overall, even though it seems like I had a largely negative experience from this review, I would say the course was net positive. I'm glad I did it at least, extra practice never hurt anyone; but I think you will have to look past some of the info and find your own solutions.

And if the ZTM ever wants to add that contact page after all...I think you should.

results.content: It's been a good introduction. I have been learning how web development evolved from HTML, CSS and JS to JQuery (Majorly to help with Browser Compatibility). In 2013, Google launched Angular JS. Angular JS was well used until it became hard to deal with complex structures. Later that year, 2013, Facebook launched React JS. Developers found more reasons to rush to React JS because of Angular JS's complete overhaul. I have learnt that architecture is important -- leading to likes of MVC. Model, View and Controller.

results.content:
Well described and layout is good.
However, there are subjects that are skipped, that assume the user understands. I am a backend developer with knowledge of front end so I was OK. However, others would struggle.

1) Please add an explanation of anonymous functions and empty () functions. This must be very early in the courses.

2) Please stop waving the cursor around something on-screen and fine a better way to highlight. There must be lots of solutions for this.

3) Please add animation to the explanations of HTTP get of HTML, CSS and JS files from a backend. i.e. some diagrams are better than others in the course.

Also, there are several statements that explain what is going on but don't show it.
I would love to work with you to improve this course. I could help to make it better.

I am still at the beginning of the course, but i do have react experience thats why i am mostly refreshing. 

But from the first tutorial Author tells:

Lets name a variable as "string"... What ??? This is extremely bad habit and completely against naming convention. 

You never ever name variable as String, Number, Boolean because its data type of variable. 

What if you have another String. Will you name it "StringTwo" ? 

Then people who never did programming before, will do this horrible mistakes.

results.content:
Udemy asks you to rate the course before you barely start so I did not realize I had given five stars already. I was compelled to change the rating because I find the teaching style of this course to be very poor. There is a lack of theory and explanation as to why things are happening and very often you'll find yourself just copying code and trying to keep up with Yihua who is typing very fast and quickly going through a concept he is talking about. 

Yihua goes so fast through his scripts at times that you'll find yourself needing to pause or slow the video down if you made a typo and have an error. What is even worse is that the end of lesson githubs are not always available during big code changes so you might need to watch something multiple times to correct any mistakes you have so you end up copy pasting more than absorbing anything.

There is very little explanation for much of the things happening and the lack of small step-throughs will make this course extremely difficult for anybody that does not have a beginner to intermediate understanding of React already. I'm not done with the course yet but as of now i'm nearly 50% through and I am not pleased with concept explanation at all.
